Home - Dr. I. Fleischer - UR Home - Dr. I. Fleischer - UR UR Home Home Members Research Publications Links Welcome to the Fleischer Laboratory Students wanted! Are you a motivated and inquisitive person and moreover, interested in organic chemistry and research? The brand new research group Fleischer needs your help! We are looking for answers to following questions: Can acids be used for the activation of double bonds where normally metal catalysts are needed? Which alternatives to carbon monoxide are there? Can we utilize thermodynamically stable carbon dioxide as a carbonyl source? Which tandem reaction sequences are yet to be discovered? The lab is awesome and empty... Send an E-mail to IF if you would like to join us! Ivana Fleischer - 21.05.2014 12:22 Fakulty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Research Group Fleischer Dr. Ivana Fleischer Office Building CH, room 23.1.85Phone ++941 943-4628 Fax ++941 943-4121 E-mail

Ivana Fleischer - 21.05.2014 12:19 Fakulty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Research Group Fleischer Dr. Ivana Fleischer Office Building CH, room 23.1.85Phone ++941 943-4628 Fax ++941 943-4121 E-mail

Research - Dr. I. Fleischer - UR Research - Dr. I. Fleischer - UR UR Home Home Members Research Publications Links Research Our research profile is based on the development of new catalytic transformations and their application in organic synthesis. Our main interrests are: Acid-catalyzed Hydrofunctionalization of Alkenes The attachement of an activating group to alkene enables replacement of traditional metal catalysts by Brønsted acids in the hydrofunctionalization of alkenes. We seek for new reactivity and transformations. New sources of "CO" Carbonylations constitute a versatile method for the construction of strategic functionalities. We are interested in the employment of surrogates for the poisonous and expensive carbon monoxide, especially carbon dioxide. Ivana Fleischer - 21.05.2014 12:19 Fakulty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Research Group Fleischer Dr. Ivana Fleischer Office Building CH, room 23.1.85Phone ++941 943-4628 Fax ++941 943-4121 E-mail

2011 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR

2011 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR 2011 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR UR Home Home Group Research Publications Teaching News 2014 2013 2012 2011 Links 2011 - How quickly nothing has happened! December Paper chase: Christiane's feature article was published in Synthesis. Samet's chlorostyrene business was awarded a hot paper status by Angewandte and can be seen in their Early View. Matthias' and Alice's work on iron-catalyzed isomerizations was the most accessed ChemCatChem communication in the past month. Good job everyone! Plenty of reasons to get wasted at tonite's x-mas party. (AJvW) This one goes out to our colleagues and loved ones around the globe: We wish you all the best for a peaceful holiday season. Be merry! Let's ring in the new and make it a good one! (AJvW) October Samet fetched a DAAD fellowship to work for three months with Martin Kotora at the Charles University in Prague (CZ). Axel's mentoring did not stop at country borders. Mid October, he stopped by for a short visit and lecture hosted by Martin and Petr Stepnicka (see photo). (AJvW) September September 30th saw a major portion of our group move boxes and lifes to the charming capital of eastern Bavaria, where the local university felt impelled to offer Axel a well-endowed position starting next day. The move went rather smoothly with most of the chemicals sticking to their assigned places in the back of the truck. To make a long story short: It's just another Department of Chemistry with the NMRs a floor down and the bathrooms in an unpleasant state. But a couple things really changed for the better: We call a technician our mate now (Michaela Lutz), and the cafeteria on ground floor boasts a beer vending machine accessible all night. Take this! (AJvW) Farewell party in Cologne with a raffle! Each ticket wins! The grand prix was Axel's office couch. It went to our friends at the Inorganic Institute. Enjoy! (SaGr) Cologne! Pfiads euch! 2012 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR

2012 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR 2012 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR UR Home Home Group Research Publications Teaching News 2014 2013 2012 2011 Links 2012 - How quickly nothing has happened! December Despite temperatures lingering around 15°C, we flee campus for the end-of-year holidays. Merry christmas, everyone! Oliver Tepner, our new colleague taking good care of the teacher's education, introduces himself to the faculty with a round of drinks and snacks. Welcome! On Dec 10, we welcome Corinne Gosmini (Palaiseau, F) to our department. She delivers a lecture on her long-standing cobalt catalysis adventures. November On Nov 7, we welcome Ivana Fleischer (Rostock). She is keen to join us as junior researcher and build an independent group. Carbon dioxide is her favourite tool. Good old Christian Hackenberger (FU Berlin) delivers a lecture in our GDCh lecture series on Nov 26. The (Hans) Carl von Carlowitz Center of Sustainable Chemistry goes public! This UR knowledge beacon bundles our activities revolving around green chemistry, catalysis, biomass transformations, and sustainable technologies. October October 12: Farewell party honouring our bioanalytics colleague Otto Wolfbeis: He retired from duty, but is still fit as a fiddle. Good luck for your new endeavours off campus! Semester start breaks loose! Some 200 students enroll for Axel's "Reaction Mechanisms" class, the notorious OrgChem bottleneck. The "Brückner" ranks high on the shopping list. Michael Hammer and Dominik Gärtner take up tutorial duties. Thanks! On Oct 29, Magnus Rueping (Aachen) visits us and unleashes a firework of organocatalysis upon us! Good stuff! September September, 2nd: We call two new group members our mates. Maria joins us as a 4th year graduate student from Bilbao. She'll work on iron-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions. Michal from Prague will start his Ph.D. work on photocatalysis projects. Welcome & good luck! Conference season. Two impressions from the ICOMC in Lisbon: Our Beilstein Lab Videos went public today! If iron is not yet your catalyst friend, please have a look at how simple coupling and cleavage reactions can be with just a hint of iron and a little Grignard as the side dish: http://www.beilstein.tv/tvpost/iron-catalysis-for-biaryl-coupling-and-ether-cleavage-reactions/ AK trip to Weimar / ORCHEM 2012 August This week brought good news. Together with his Berlin colleague Christian Hackenberger, Axel will be awarded the 2012 ORCHEM Young Researcher Prize at the meeting in Weimar in late September. The new Shanghai University Ranking just came out! In Chemistry, the UR jumped from nowhere into the 151-200th place range, a tied 14th rank within Germany. With roughly 200 countries on our mother planet, you do the math! Congratulations, UR! Our elderly colleague Oliver Reiser turns 50 on Aug 11! Congratulations! He spares no penny and invites family, friends, and colleagues to a sportful and satiable night out at the "Leerer Beutel". Thank you! Beilstein TV shoots a filmlet of the scenic campus and also catches an insider view on our iron chemistry. Samet and Dominik play starring roles in what is a chemistry version of the Stones' Paint it Black: "... no colors anymore I want them to turn black ..." It's not easy facing up when your whole world is black ;-) http://www.beilstein.tv/tvpost/iron-catalysis-for-biaryl-coupling-and-ether-cleavage-reactions/ July Hundreds of catalysis aficionados flocked to summerly Munich to attend the International Conference on Catalysis (ICC). Axel gave a lecture on "Olefin Effects in Iron-Catalyzed Coupling Reactions". We welcome Bas de Bruin (Amsterdam), Tehshik Yoon (Wisconsin), and Reinhard W. Hoffmann (Marburg) as speakers of the Chemistry colloquia series just before the summer break. On July 19, our joint summer party with the Wolf group takes place at the sun deck. We also cater to the folks of the mechanic, glass, and electronic workshops and analytical department and thank them for their assistance throughout the season. June It's EURO crunch time! In the semifinal, the well-prepared early favourites Germany unexpectedly lost to the media-battered Italians who had the criminal prosecutors closing in on them. With GER and POR out of the race, it came down to Italy and Spain battling it out. Spain made it and fetched the European crown with a memorable 4:0 win. Congratulations! Now, it's back to work for the German team and us. June 12th marked the start of a tradition! It's the birthday of Anton Vilsmeier, a son of Regensburg and now the name patron of the newly established "Anton Vilsmeier Lecture" at the UR. This year, Prof. em. Rolf Huisgen delivered the first Vilsmeier Lecture. Students and faculty flocked in large numbers to this event. Prof. Christoph Meinel and Axel gave introductory speeches on Vilsmeier's life and legacy. June, 29th. The last Cologne kid is off the block. Anna Weber wrapped-up her dissertation and successfully defended her thesis in Regensburg. The red Ph.D. trolley was dedusted and made it's first moves on UR grounds. ...change of location, but with a fine tradition!... The 30+ °C after Anna's defense prompted us to re-new our group photographs (beer cart not in picture, some bottles hidden behind backs!). Last weekend, Regensburg appeared on its best. With the opening of the Thurn & Taxis Music Festival at the Regensburg Palace, the Ostengassen Festival, and the medieval Spectaculum at the Danube riverside, there were plenty of opportunities to enjoy hometurf. May Together with our non-organic fellows of the Wolf group, we organized the FeUR mini symposium in early June. A spectular line-up and the perfectly trained crew made a go of this two-day get-together. This thematic mini symposium at the University of Regensburg revolved around the use of iron complexes in synthesis, catalysis, and energy supply ? and was the first of its kind. The FeUR served two purposes as an XXL version of Robert?s and Axel?s inaugural lectures and a meeting of the minds in the area of iron catalysis. The lectures, poster session, and chats over a cup of coffee and mug of beer provided multiple opportunities to stimulate interactions and strengthen the links between various research directions in the rapidly developing field of iron catalysis. We are especially grateful to the supporters of this mini symposium: Vielberth foundation of the UR, Fonds der Chemischen Industrie, German Chemical Society, BASF Ludwigshafen, ChemSusChem, and the local DFG graduate college on Photocatalysis. April Time has flown by. Today, we have met our industrial collaborators from Saltigo GmbH Leverkusen for the first time in 6 months. The coming months will see us go along new avenues in our catalysis projects. The iron is still hot! (AJvW) Snow has been spotted in the Regensburg area. Anyway, Happy Easter everyone! April 11, 2012: Today, we hooked up the 1000 Euro CO bottle and set up the first ever carbonylation reaction of our Regensburg days. We dedicate this experiment to Matthias Beller on the occasion of his 50th birthday. Happy birthday! Alice's paper on iron-catalyzed hydrogenations and spectroscopic studies of the heterogeneous catalysts, a collaborative effort with Matthias Bauer (now at Kaiserslautern), has been accepted for publication in ChemCatChem. Congratulations! March Finally, we call an MBraun UniLab our mate! The white beauty moved into the night lab and has already won the hearts of the entire catalysis subgroup. We feed her only the very best, Argon 5.0 that is! By the way, this is the first ever glovebox entering organic chemistry grounds at the UR. (AJvW) Two more aesthetic rectifications: (1) The new door windows let the sun into the once bleak lab corridors and (2) allow a glance of our new poster frames. (AJvW) February A secondment of the UR chem faculty left home turf for a friendly visit to the Bay of Bengal in Tamil Nadu, India. There, the Ideal Beach Resort at Mahabalipuram, also an impressive site of ancient temples dating from the 7th and 8th century, hosted the Indigo research conference. Junior and senior researchers from Regensburg, Munich, Braunschweig, 11 Indian IITs and other ivy league institutions took part and lifted the Indigo network to the next level. The tight schedule left hardly any gaps for a swim in the surf or dunk in the pool. A hand-picked selection of toughnecks travelled on to Hyderabad to probe the karma of a potential collaboration with folks at the IICT. The Charminar monument DID have a lasting impression... (AJvW) January The AK JvW wishes everyone a successful, creative, and Happy New Year! Where is the snow? It doesn't snow until Alice returns from her holidays in Cologne, so she doesn't miss out on her early morning snow sweeping in front of her Regensburg mansion. She'll come back next week :-). (SaGr) Pimping the analytics: Our new Agilent GC-FID is up and running! It's about time that we start cranking out some serious crude product sample collections. During the past and coming weeks, we have the builders in the lab. There's still plenty of piping, wiring, and clamping to be done. The argon, CO, and hydrogen supplies are next on the agenda. (AJvW) In early January our group finally re-united with Samet's return from Prague. We gave our lab warming party on Feb 2 with plenty of booze and bites. The crowds came early and stayed late. The first dance moves were spotted at around 9 p.m.The last beer was flushed at 3:30 a.m. Good job, everyone! (SaGr+AJvW) Sad news reached us this week. Former chemistry professor Andreas Merz deceased on Jan 22, 2012. He retired as Professor of Organic Chemistry from the University of Regensburg in 2005 and was known for his contributions to the synthesis and electrochemistry of heteroarenes and organic dyes. A snapshot of one of his colourful compounds and its oxidized state that both show dimeric behaviour in solution and the solid state are given below. (AJvW) The thematic mini symposium "FeUR" on June 4-5 is rapidly approaching and the agenda taking shape. For further details, please see the symposium's webpage: http://www.ur.de/events/feur/index.html Another puzzle piece to ameliorate our lab infrastructure: Two high-pressure reactors from Parr have arrived and are now hooked to the gas supplies. Starting today, reams of H2 and CO molecules will be unleashed on unsaturated molecules. We put an end to the balloony times! (AJvW) Axel Jacobi von Wangelin - 01.01.2014 11:55 Faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Research Group Axel Jacobi von Wangelin Building CH, 13.1.82Phone +49 (0)941 943-4802 Fax +49

2013 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR

2013 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR 2013 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR UR Home Home Group Research Publications Teaching News 2014 2013 2012 2011 Links 2013 December The winter is here and puts snow flakes outside, goose bumps on our skins and the university heating system to a serious test. Hard lab work at a forced rate now also serves a heating purpose. Josef embraces his paternal role and leaves for some serious home work around his 1-year old. Good luck! Dec. 10: Christmas dinner no. 1 at the Hexerei, a cosy Austrian-run restaurant. Käsespätzle, Kaiserschmarrn, lots of beer and wine! A good package to gain some extra pounds for the winter season! November Hendrik Dietz (TUM) delivers a GDCh lecture on DNA materials. Miroslav Fojta (Brno) made Regensburg a stop on his Heyrovsky-Ilkovic-Nernst Award tour through Germany. My A-level classmate Anke Krüger (Würzburg) visits the institute with a riveting lecture on nanodiamonds. Tim returns safely from his Balkan trip and takes up work in the ionic liquid business. He convinced the Evonik foundation to pay his bills! October In early October, another INDIGO meeting takes place at the UR. We enjoy the company of our 20 or so IIT colleagues, they get a taste of the early autumn chill. Alois Fürstner (MPI Muelheim) delivers two excellent keynote lectures. October 14 marks the start of the winter teaching term. Our institute faces great challenges with the double B.Sc. class of 2011 entering the advanced organic labs. Key to happiness is that we also increased the headcount on the teacher's side with three new hires: Ivana Fleischer joined us as an independent group leader from the Leibniz Institute of Catalysis where she worked with Matthias Beller. Olga Garcia Mancheno (ex-Muenster) accepted a W2 call at the UR and the nearby Science Campus Straubing. David Diaz Diaz returns to our institute from Spain with a prestigious Humboldt professorship. Welcome everyone! Oct. 29: Dieter Enders (Aachen) kicks off the GDCh lecture series with a fireworks display of organocatalysis methodologies. Axel is elected in absentia to become new head of the local GDCh section while visiting the TU Chemnitz. September "Blue Collar of the Month" award goes to Dominik! He pushed a nightshift to finalize kinetic and spectroscopic measurements for a high-flying cobalt catalysis manuscript. Good job! The collected data show no weariness. We still wonder how to accommodate his dedication in a scholarly way in the supporting info... Axel tours the U.K. and delivers lectures at the Universities of Bath, St. Andrews, Edinburgh and Glasgow (Strathclyde) and a chalk & talk presentation at the Organic Chemistry meeting in Gregynog (Wales). Thanks to Steve Thomas for organizing and all local folks for wit, chat, inspiration, and hospitality! Tim submits his Master thesis and chips in a So Long! He'll be touring the Balkans all the way to Istanbul. On the day of his departure, he learns of his Evonik fellowship. Congratulations! The 2nd South African-German OrgChem Conference (BOCC) in Tutzing concludes the month of September. Dominik and Axel enjoy entertaining lectures, the lakeside setting, and a trips to Kloster Andechs and the Buchheim Museum. We thank Hagga (Cologne) for hooking us up with our far-travelled friends! August Holiday season! Tranquility and clean bathrooms; no students around. Quite a good trade! We have discharged a couple of papers and proposals from our pipelines and enjoyed the lower 30s °C on campus and riverside hangouts. July The Professoral pub crawl called at the riverside "Banane" and bid farewell to this dearly beloved hangout. The Banane fell prey to the real estate rallye which has gotten a grip on Regensburg lately. Tropical heat in the upper 30s resides in Regensburg at the end of July. While lab work is a menace to our high spirits, we spur our bikes and pay the oldest German monastery a visit. Kloster Weltenburg, 40 km from Regensburg alongside River Danube, also hosts one of the better breweries in the country which makes for a pleasant sampling stop. For a little more cultural depth, we spare no pains and scale up to the Liberation Hall overlooking the Danube at Kelheim. Fabiana Filace joins our group as an exchange student from the Universidad de Alcala (E). Welcome! She'll be shining some light onto carbonylation and other reactions. June End of June is the start of the exams rallye. This year Axel takes some 55 (!) or so oral examinations. The hopes of 4th, 6th, and 10th semester students are high-flying. Good luck everyone! The 2013 Leiden-Ranking puts Regensburg on the winner's podium. We fetch a well-deserved third place among German natural science faculties with a fair margin before Freiburg, Münster, TU Munich, Aachen etc. Who knows what it's good for... June 12: The Anton Vilsmeier Lecture turns 2! 2005 Nobel laureate Prof. Richard Schrock (MIT) is the honour lecturer this year. His lecture on "Nitrogen Fixation" will be sandwiched by the "Chemistry Day" featuring warm welcome notes, academic year reviews, student poster exhibitions, graduation awarding ceremonies, and heavy feasting. Generous funding by the local Hans Vielberth Foundation is gratefully acknowledged. 06/06/13, 11:33 a.m.: A little baby-girl is born into the already bodacious lives of Axel, Luise, and Hanno. Thanks for all cheers and wishes! May Visitor influx: Rainer Herges (Kiel), Manuel Alcarazo (Mülheim), Hansjörg Grützmacher (Zürich) and Stephen Thomas (Edinburgh) pay us lecture visits. Mid May, we receive good news: The Fund of the Chemical Industry has awarded a prestigious Liebig grant to Ivana Fleischer. Ivana is currently a postdoc with Matthias Beller at the LIKAT in Rostock and will join our institute as independent group leader this late summer. April Good news: Josef returns in fair conditions after doctors have patched up his ankles. Soccer might be a sport of the under-30s from now on. Stick to the touchline! Double punch: Today, Michal received two e-mails from the Chem. Commun. and Angew. Chem. editorial offices, both of which stating the acceptance of his manuscripts on photo-catalytic reactions. Congratulations! Ph.D. defense reloaded: Alice calls it a day and returns to her Cologne homebase for good. She left final marks with a successful Ph.D. defense and blithe farewell party. Congratulations and all the best! Monday, April 8th: The new lab course "Technikum: Gase, Drücke, Vakuum" has its first appearance in the undergraduate curriculum. Various groups of the Inorganic, Organic, and Physical Institutes have teamed up to teach students the minutiae of inert gas, high-pressure and vacuum techniques. Our group entertains experiments dealing with the handling of high-pressure reactors, gloveboxes, and gas supplies. Michal received the Best Lecture Award at the Czech and Slovak Student's Conference of Natural Sciences held at Comenius University on April 24, 2013 for his oral presentation on "Photocatalytic Alkylthiolations of Arenes". Congratulations! The last Cologne migrant worker abandons the team: On April 25th, Samet finalizes his Regensburg stay and heads as a newly wed to his new home base in Rostock. Good luck! The group gathers at Bismarckplatz for a round of farewell drinks. March Marching Out: This month sees Sabine cross the finish line. Congratulations and good luck for the job hunt! At the end of an eventful week with Sabine's graduation and farewell party and the quarterly graduate college get-together and a splendid lecture double feature by Uli Jahn (Prague), the group is craving for the Easter holidays. Our contribution to the "Germany & Brazil 2013-2014" year "where ideas connect": We welcome Andre Luiz Stein from Brazil to the group. He's a final year graduate student from Prof. Gilson Zeni's group at Federal University of Santa Maria and will pay a 6-month research visit to our labs. Metal-catalyzed deoxygenations will be on his agenda. Axel and Tim attend the DECHEMA Catalysis meeting in Weimar, where Axel gives a lecture on our newest cobalt catalysis endeavours. Right after this trip he bows out of office for a surely deserved 2-week trip through Andalusia. February Head hunt: In early February, we roll out the carpet for six excellent candidates that queue up for an Organic chemistry vacancy. The position is halved between our and the neighboring Straubing Science Campus. Catalysis, biomass, and reactor technology are the buzzwords! End of term rallye: Feb 11 means high noon for 180 2nd years and their aspirations to sail thru the "Organic Reaction Mechanisms" bottleneck. Chinese crack and library hard copies of the "Brückner" are in high demand! Good luck, everyone! January Friendly fire: Nuno Maulide (Mülheim) pays us a visit and delivers a round of free drinks and piano tunes just after his riveting talk on some off-the-beaten-track reactions. Good stuff (all of it)! We welcome Josef and Tim as new crew. Josef, a young dad of a month-old boy, takes up work in the photo-oxidation business. Tim safely returned from a round-the-globe trip and will put nanoparticles to some serious use. Good luck! Happy New Year, all you followers! Axel Jacobi von Wangelin - 01.01.2014 12:25 Faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Research Group Axel Jacobi von Wangelin Building CH, 13.1.82Phone +49 (0)941 943-4802 Fax +49

2014 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR

2014 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR 2014 - Prof. Dr. A. Jacobi von Wangelin - UR UR Home Home Group Research Publications Teaching News 2014 2013 2012 2011 Links 2014 June Anna's and Josef's manuscript on three-component cyclizations toward cis and trans-cyclohexenediamines with over 70 synthesized products has been accepted at Org. Biomol. Chem. Congratulations! June 12: Vilsmeier - no. 3! Anton Vilsmeier, the most famous chemical son of our city, died on this very day 120 years ago. This year, Prof. Josef Michl (Boulder & Prague) is our guest lecturer and he delivered! His entertaining talk on the role of free lithium ions as polymerization catalysts is sandwiched between departmental "Science Day" activities and various dietary feasts. Despite the competition from outside 30° temperatures and the nearby campus fest, the attendance is very well! May Never cast a clout till May be out! Germany is gripped by an early May chill. Our lab temperatures drop to 11°C on Monday morning! Thermal reactions are high on the agenda this week! Michal's and Fabiana's mechanistic study on photo-catalyzed reactions gives "open access" a meaning: This paper made it into the top notch of the most clicked articles of Beilstein J. Org. Chem.! RedCrossElectroCoRe - Are you ready for a new tune? Chem. Eur. J. has mopped the bait and published our concept article on reductive cross-electrophile coupling reactions. They also posted it on facebook, obviously to attract a young crowd(?). Matteo is recipient of a Kekule doctoral fellowship from the Fonds der Chemischen Industrie (FCI). Congratulations to this accolade! April We welcome a new apprentice to the crew. Patrick takes up work hand in hand with Michaela Lutz. Theresa has moved on and soon will prepare for her final exams. Good luck! The spring semester starts on April 8th. With Axel on parental leave, there's only two undergaduate labs to be supervised by the group. The summer term also lures superb lecturers to Regensburg. Ferdi Schüth, Klaus Roth, Klaus Hahn and Judith Howard will deliver lectures in the GDCh colloquia series on mondays. The Organic Institute hosted Jose Aleman (Madrid), Günter Kreisel (Jena), Radovan Sebesta (Bratislava) and David Nicewicz (Chapel Hill) in April. The 2014 Leiden Ranking (a university town in NL and not to be confused with its German translation) again put Regensburg in the top 10 of European Natural Sciences faculties. Lausanne, Cambridge, St. Andrews, and the ETH head the pack while the UR is trailed by Konstanz and LMU Munich. March Axel swaps student tutoring for baby pampering. From March until August, he'll be on parental leave. While only occasionally checking on the team's whereabouts, Sabine Amslinger will carry the teaching burdens. The group attends two conferences: Paderborn hosts this years Chemiedozententagung - always a good occasion to see some new bloods in the field and strike up chats with long-time-no-see companions. Just after this, the German Catalysis Society holds its annual scientific get-together in Weimar, the home of classicism. February End-of-semester rallye with final examinations for numerous B.Sc., M.Sc. and Ph.D. students and Organic Chemistry lectures delivered by Morten Grötli and Gerhard Hilt. After this, Axel loosens up during Carnival in Cologne. January Happy New Year! The JvW group extend their best wishes to all colleagues, friends, and family around the world. Be 2014 another exciting and inspiring year for all of you! We welcome Matteo Villa to the crew. Matteo just graduated from the University of Milan (Italy) with a M.Sc. degree in Industrial Chemistry (Prof. F. Ragaini). He'll boost our efforts toward the preparation and application of nanoparticulate catalysts, design new well-defined homogeneous complexes of 3d metals, and set up a collaboration with his former group at Milano. Tobias Burger and Efrain Reyes-Rodriguez join us as Master students taking up lab work toward photo-catalytic aromatic substitutions and iron-catalyzed cascade reactions, respectively. Good luck! Two new papers in the pipeline: Our collaborative works with the Wolf and Prechtl groups have led to publications that were just accepted by Angew. Chem. and Chem. Commun., respectively. Congratulations to all folks involved! The final examinations on "Organic Reaction Mechanisms", traditionally a serious bottleneck in the B.Sc. curriculum, come upon students already on January 25th. Good luck! Axel Jacobi von Wangelin - 14.06.2014 10:20 Faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Research Group Axel Jacobi von Wangelin Building CH, 13.1.82Phone +49 (0)941 943-4802 Fax +49

Molecular Recognition - Prof. B. König - UR

Molecular Recognition - Prof. B. König - UR Molecular Recognition - Prof. B. König - UR UR Home Home Prof. Dr. B. König F-Praktikum Research Molecular Recognition Chemical Photocatalysis Sustainable Chemistry Medicinal Chemistry Teaching Chemistry Chromatographie Labs and Offices Members Responsible for Publications Lectures Molecular Recognition Molecular Recognition with functionalized vesicles or surfaces The selective molecular recognition of protein structures and protein surfaces is essential for many tasks in bioanalysis and diagnostic. Antibodies provide high specificity and affinity, but they are intrinsically labile, costly in preparation and not available for all epitopes. Synthetic probes may provide alternatives for some applications. We use the cooperative action of reversible coordinative bonds, hydrogen bonds and luminescent dyes embedded into vesicles or surfaces to achieve a selective and high affinity binding to peptides and proteins under physio­logical conditions. The findings may pave the way to the development of synthetic antibodies. Representative recent publications Britta Badziura - 20.12.2013 11:45 Faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Research Group König Prof. Dr. Burkhard König E-mailSekretariat Viola Rappenegger Room CH32.1.85 Phone +49 941 943-4575 Fax +49 941 943-1717

Molecular Recognition - Prof. B. König - UR Molecular Recognition - Prof. B. König - UR UR Home Home Prof. Dr. B. König F-Praktikum Research Molecular Recognition Chemical Photocatalysis Sustainable Chemistry Medicinal Chemistry Teaching Chemistry Chromatographie Labs and Offices Members Responsible for Publications Lectures Molecular Recognition Molecular Recognition with functionalized vesicles or surfaces The selective molecular recognition of protein structures and protein surfaces is essential for many tasks in bioanalysis and diagnostic. Antibodies provide high specificity and affinity, but they are intrinsically labile, costly in preparation and not available for all epitopes. Synthetic probes may provide alternatives for some applications. We use the cooperative action of reversible coordinative bonds, hydrogen bonds and luminescent dyes embedded into vesicles or surfaces to achieve a selective and high affinity binding to peptides and proteins under physio­logical conditions. The findings may pave the way to the development of synthetic antibodies. Representative recent publications Britta Badziura - 20.12.2013 11:45 Faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Research Group König Prof. Dr. Burkhard König E-mailSekretariat Viola Rappenegger Room CH32.1.85 Phone +49 941 943-4575 Fax +49 941 943-1717
Chemical Photocatalysis - Prof. B. König - UR

Chemical Photocatalysis - Prof. B. König - UR Chemical Photocatalysis - Prof. B. König - UR UR Home Home Prof. Dr. B. König F-Praktikum Research Molecular Recognition Chemical Photocatalysis Sustainable Chemistry Medicinal Chemistry Teaching Chemistry Chromatographie Labs and Offices Members Responsible for Publications Lectures Chemical Photokatalysis Chemical Photocatalysis Using visible light for (enantio)selective organic transformations We develop selective chemical photocatalysts for endothermic or kinetically hindered organic reactions and describe the key parameters of their design and function. This will pave the way to a broader use of solar energy for chemical transformations. The photocatalysts consist of a redox active chromophore (sensitizer) and a catalytic unit or substrate binding site. Irradiation with light induces a charge separation between the electron donor and the electron acceptor unit of the photocatalyst, which is coupled to a subsequent chemical reaction. The charge separation may occur within the photocatalyst or between the photocatalyst and a bound substrate. The absorbed light energy contributes to the overall energy balance of the reaction and is thereby transformed into chemically stored energy or substitutes reagents, which are otherwise necessary to achieve conversion. Although the physical primary steps of a photocatalysis are considered to be well understood, a description of electron transfer is provided by the Marcus-theory and mechanisms of catalysis are thoroughly investigated, a rational design of efficient photocatalysts is still very difficult: To achieve an effective photocatalysis the exact kinetic, energetic and geometric coupling of electronic and chemical steps is necessary. Catalyses involving one electron transfer processes, such as radical cyclizations, or two electron transfer processes, e.g. two coupled redox transformations, are investigated in interdisciplinary research projects. Whenever possible, the visible part of the solar light spectrum is used as energy source. The structures of the photocatalysts are systematically varied and thermodynamic and kinetic key parameters are determined. We expect from the detailed spectroscopic analysis and theoretical description of the photoreactions a better understanding of the important and general parameters describing an effective coupling of primary photo processes and subsequent chemical reactions. Model systems of biological photosynthesis and photovoltaic devices are explicitly excluded from the research program. Representative recent publications Britta Badziura - 20.12.2013 11:45 Faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Research Group König Prof. Dr. Burkhard König E-mailSekretariat Viola Rappenegger Room CH32.1.85 Phone +49 941 943-4575 Fax +49 941 943-1717

Sustainable Chemistry - Prof. B. König - UR

Sustainable Chemistry - Prof. B. König - UR Sustainable Chemistry - Prof. B. König - UR UR Home Home Prof. Dr. B. König F-Praktikum Research Molecular Recognition Chemical Photocatalysis Sustainable Chemistry Medicinal Chemistry Teaching Chemistry Chromatographie Labs and Offices Members Responsible for Publications Lectures Sustainable Chemistry Sustainable Chemistry Catalytic conversion of carbohydrates into fine chemicals While the methodic arsenal of organic synthesis using fossil carbon resources has been highly developed over the last 100 years, there is a considerable lack of synthetic routes being in accordance with the rules of sustainable chemistry for the efficient transformation of complex and highly functionalized bulk natural products into fine chemicals or functionalized materials. Our target compounds are value chemicals, which are obtained by selective catalytic transformation of abundant carbohydrates. Representative recent publications Carl von Carlowitz Center für Nachhaltige Chemie Projektverbund ForCycle - Rohstoffwende Bayern Zucker-Harnstoffgemsiche zur Extraktion von Metallen Britta Badziura - 05.06.2014 15:01 Faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Research Group König Prof. Dr. Burkhard König E-mailSekretariat Viola Rappenegger Room CH32.1.85 Phone +49 941 943-4575 Fax +49 941 943-1717

The investigations are done in close collaborations with research teams from pharmacy, molecular biology of medicine. Link - Prof. B. König - UR Link - Prof. B. König - UR UR Home Home Prof. Dr. B. König F-Praktikum Research Teaching Chemistry A New Organic Teaching Lab Chemical experiments Chromatographie Labs and Offices Members Responsible for Publications Lectures A New Organic Teaching Lab - Neues OC Praktikum (NOP) Sustainability in science and technology begins when we start thinking how to solve a problem or how to turn science into technology. Chemical processes, designed and developed to have maximum efficiency, lead to sustainable chemical production. Of key importance is therefore the mindset of the people working in science and engineering. To achieve better awareness of the important issues of sustainability in chemistry within the next generation of scientists, the traditional course content of chemistry classes must be changed. To provide the necessary material for the organic chemistry teaching lab course, which is part of almost all study programs in chemistry, we develop and collect material that allows students and teachers to assess reactions beyond experimental set up, reaction mechanism and chemical yield. The project, which is a joint effort of seven German universities, is financed by the Deutsche Bundesstiftung Umwelt (German Environmental Foundation). Go to www.oc-praktikum.de to see results. Britta Badziura - 20.12.2013 10:48 Faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Research Group König Prof. Dr. Burkhard König E-mailSekretariat Viola Rappenegger Room CH32.1.85 Phone +49 941 943-4575 Fax +49 941 943-1717

Link - Prof. B. König - UR Link - Prof. B. König - UR UR Home Home Prof. Dr. B. König F-Praktikum Research Teaching Chemistry A New Organic Teaching Lab Chemical experiments Chromatographie Labs and Offices Members Responsible for Publications Lectures Chemical experiments for primary school kids The year 2003, which is the year of chemistry in Germany, has seen a special activity in Regensburg. Sponsored by a grant from the Stifterverband für die Deutsche Wissenschaft (Program PUSH: Public Understanding of Science and Humanities) the faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy teamed up with the primary school pedagogics and visited local primary schools to do chemical experiments together with the kids. Several modules for use in the second, third and fourth grade were developed and a set of material was put together. For more information,see: http://www.chemie-im-alltag.de/articles/0065/index.html. To give all kids that could not be visited in class a taste of chemistry a chemical demonstration lecture - especially for kids - was held. Biologie Organisches Praktikum OCP I, CH und BC OCP II, CH OCP I, Lehramt OCP II, Lehramt OCP I, Biologie B.Sc. Alumni & Emeriti Links Intranet OC Organisches Praktikum I (Bio) für Studierende der Biologie (B.Sc.) Vorankündigung Wintersemester 2014/2015 Vorlesungsverzeichnis 53531 (5 SWS), Prof. O. Reiser, Dr. P. Kreitmeier Für das Praktikum werden im WS 13/14 zwei Termine angeboten: Termin 1: 8.9.2014 bis 26.10.2014, ganztägig Mo - Fr, 9.00 - 18.00 Uhr Termin 2: Voraussichtlich 6.10.2014 bis 28.11.2014, Mo -Do, 13.00 - 18.00 Uhr. Die Klausur zum Praktikum findet gemeinsam mit der Klausur zur Vorlesung OC II für Studierende der Biologie und der Lehrämter statt. Anmeldung zum Praktikum Für das Praktikum ist aus organisatorischen Gründen eine (Vor)Anmeldung notwendig. Diese Anmeldung wird ab 2. Juni in elektronischer Form von dieser Seite aus möglich sein: Anmeldeseite zum Praktikum Rückfragen bitte an Dr. Peter Kreitmeier, Raum CH 33.1.83. Anmeldung zum Praktikum Für das Praktikum ist aus organisatorischen Gründen eine (Vor)Anmeldung notwendig. Diese Anmeldung wird ab 2. Juni in elektronischer Form von dieser Seite aus möglich sein. Biologen können sich bei dieser Anmeldung entweder für den 1. oder 2. Praktikumstermin eintragen (Wunschtermin). Wegen der beschränkten Zahl an Praktikumsplätzen können wir nicht gewährleisten, dass jeder Studiende sein Praktikum zum gewählten Wunschtermin absolvieren kann. Deshalb werden die verfügbaren Plätze nach den erreichten Punkten aus der Klausur Grundvolesung OC, 2. Sem. vergeben. Je mehr Punkte, desto höher die Chancen auf den Wunschtermin. Die endgültige Praktikumseinteilung erfolgt nach Bekanntgabe der Klausurergebnisse OC Grundvorlesung. Rückfragen bitte an Dr. Peter Kreitmeier, Raum CH 33.1.83. Vorbesprechung und Platzübernahme: Vorbespechung mit Sicherheitseinführung für den Termin 1 ist am 8. September 2014, 9.00 Uhr, zusammen mit den Studierenden der Lehrämter (Die Teilnahme ist Pflicht!). Ab 13.00 Uhr Platzübernahme. Vorbespechung mit Sicherheitseinführung für den Termin 2 ist am voraussichtlich am Montag 6. Oktober 2014, 13.00 Uhr, anschließend Platzübernahme. Auch hier ist die Teilnahme Pflicht!. Bitte beachten Sie, dass parallel zum 2. Termin auch ein Praktikum Physik für Biologen stattfindet (in Gruppen). Um Überschneidungen mit diesem Praktikum und der Sicherheitsunterweisung zu vermeiden bitte ich alle Teilnehmer des 2. Kurses nicht in die Montagsgruppen des Physik-Praktikums zu gehen. Skripten zum Praktikum Das Praktikum besteht aus 2 Teilen: Der 1. Teil ist ein methodenorientiertes Praktikum zur präparativen Organischen Chemie. Die Versuchsvorschriften erhalten Sie bei der Vorbesprechung. Zusätzliche Literatur zu den Arbeitsmethoden: Hünig, Kreitmeier, Märkl, Sauer, "Arbeitsmethoden in der Organischen Chemie" (Buchhandlung Lehmanns, 19,95 EURO oder im Internet: www.ioc-praktikum.de. Im 2. Teil werden Sie individuelle Versuche durchführen. Die Ihnen zugeteilten Versuche erhalten Sie in der 1. Praktikumswoche, die Versuchsvorschriften können Sie dem Praktikumsskript entnehmen: Organisch-Chemisches Praktikum 1 für Studierende der Biologie und der Lehrämter (pdf, 3.3 MB) Leistungsnachweis Die erfolgreiche Teilnahme am Praktikum wird für Studierende nach der neuen LPO als Modulleistung in FlexNow bestätigt. Dazu müssen folgende Bedingungen erfüllt sein: Alle Versuche wurden erfolgreich durchgeführt und die zugehörigen Protokolle bis spätestens 16.11.2013 (Termin 1) bzw. 29.01.2014 (Termin 2) von ihrem Assistent testiert sein. Die gemeinsame Klausur zur Vorlesung Organische Chemie II für Studierende der Biologie und der Lehrämter (3. Sem.) wurde mindestens mit der Note 4.0 bestanden. Die Note wird durch die gemeinsame Klausur zur Vorlesung Organische Chemie II für Studierende der Biologie und der Lehrämter (3. Sem.) bestimmt. Bitte beachten Sie, dass Sie sich sowohl zum Praktikum als auch zur Vorlesung in FlexNow anmelden müssen. Peter Kreitmeier - 30.05.2014 17:37 Fakultät für Chemie und Pharmazie Institut für Organische Chemie Organisches Praktikum Universität RegensburgUniversitätsstr. 31 93053 Regensburg

Biologen können sich bei dieser Anmeldung entweder für den 1. oder 2. Praktikumstermin eintragen (Wunschtermin). Wegen der beschränkten Zahl an Praktikumsplätzen können wir nicht gewährleisten, dass jeder Studiende sein Praktikum zum gewählten Wunschtermin absolvieren kann. Deshalb werden die verfügbaren Plätze nach den erreichten Punkten aus der Klausur Grundvolesung OC, 2. Sem. vergeben. Je mehr Punkte, desto höher die Chancen auf den Wunschtermin. Die endgültige Praktikumseinteilung erfolgt nach Bekanntgabe der Klausurergebnisse OC Grundvorlesung. Rückfragen bitte an Dr. Peter Kreitmeier, Raum CH 33.1.83. Vorbesprechung und Platzübernahme: Vorbespechung mit Sicherheitseinführung für den Termin 1 ist am 8. September 2014, 9.00 Uhr, zusammen mit den Studierenden der Lehrämter (Die Teilnahme ist Pflicht!). Ab 13.00 Uhr Platzübernahme. Vorbespechung mit Sicherheitseinführung für den Termin 2 ist am voraussichtlich am Montag 6. Oktober 2014, 13.00 Uhr, anschließend Platzübernahme. Auch hier ist die Teilnahme Pflicht!. Bitte beachten Sie, dass parallel zum 2. Termin auch ein Praktikum Physik für Biologen stattfindet (in Gruppen). Um Überschneidungen mit diesem Praktikum und der Sicherheitsunterweisung zu vermeiden bitte ich alle Teilnehmer des 2. Kurses nicht in die Montagsgruppen des Physik-Praktikums zu gehen. Skripten zum Praktikum Das Praktikum besteht aus 2 Teilen: Der 1. Teil ist ein methodenorientiertes Praktikum zur präparativen Organischen Chemie. Die Versuchsvorschriften erhalten Sie bei der Vorbesprechung. Zusätzliche Literatur zu den Arbeitsmethoden: Hünig, Kreitmeier, Märkl, Sauer, "Arbeitsmethoden in der Organischen Chemie" (Buchhandlung Lehmanns, 19,95 EURO oder im Internet: www.ioc-praktikum.de. Im 2. Teil werden Sie individuelle Versuche durchführen. Die Ihnen zugeteilten Versuche erhalten Sie in der 1. Praktikumswoche, die Versuchsvorschriften können Sie dem Praktikumsskript entnehmen: Organisch-Chemisches Praktikum 1 für Studierende der Biologie und der Lehrämter (pdf, 3.3 MB) Leistungsnachweis Die erfolgreiche Teilnahme am Praktikum wird für Studierende nach der neuen LPO als Modulleistung in FlexNow bestätigt. Dazu müssen folgende Bedingungen erfüllt sein: Alle Versuche wurden erfolgreich durchgeführt und die zugehörigen Protokolle bis spätestens 16.11.2013 (Termin 1) bzw. 29.01.2014 (Termin 2) von ihrem Assistent testiert sein. Die gemeinsame Klausur zur Vorlesung Organische Chemie II für Studierende der Biologie und der Lehrämter (3. Sem.) wurde mindestens mit der Note 4.0 bestanden. Die Note wird durch die gemeinsame Klausur zur Vorlesung Organische Chemie II für Studierende der Biologie und der Lehrämter (3. Sem.) bestimmt. Bitte beachten Sie, dass Sie sich sowohl zum Praktikum als auch zur Vorlesung in FlexNow anmelden müssen. Peter Kreitmeier - 30.05.2014 17:37 Faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Universität RegensburgUniversitätsstr. 31 D-93053 Regensburg

Organisches Praktikum - Organische Chemie - UR Organisches Praktikum - Organische Chemie - UR Fakultäten Home Veranstaltungen Forschung Studium Kurse B.Sc. Chemie Kurse M.Sc. Chemie Kurse LA Chemie Kurse B.Sc. Biochemie Kurse M.Sc. Biochemie Kurse B.Sc. Biologie Kurse M.Sc. Biologie Organisches Praktikum OCP I, CH und BC OCP II, CH OCP I, Lehramt OCP II, Lehramt OCP I, Biologie B.Sc. Alumni & Emeriti Links Intranet OC Organisches Praktikum In der Chemie sind die experimentellen Fähigkeiten außerordentlich wichtig. Insbesondere die Organische Chemie ist im wesentlichen synthetisch orientiert. Aber auch Studierende der Biochemie und Biologie benötigen grundlegende Kenntnisse in der Durchführung von Experimenten und im Umgang mit Chemikalien und Geräten. Die organischen Praktika vermitteln diese Fertigkeiten und zeigen gleichzeitig die praktische Anwendung und Umsetzung der theoretischen Grundlagen in eigenen Experimenten. Grundpraktika Alle Grundpraktika werden intensiv durch Assisteneten betreut und gliedern sich in zwei Teile: Im ersten Teil werden die wichtigsten Arbeitsschritte der präparativen Organischen Chemie erklärt und praktisch durchgeführt. Dabei stehen der fachgerechte und sichere Aufbau der Apparaturen und die zugrundliegenden physikalisch-chemischen Prinzipien im Vordergrund. Im zweiten Teil werden von den Studierenden individuelle Versuche durchgeführt. Die erhaltenen Produkte werden gereinigt und durch spektroskopische Methoden charakterisiert. Jeder Versuch beginnt mit einem sogenannten Vortestat, in dem sicherheitstechnische Fragen behandelt werden, aber auch Aspekte der Reaktionsdurchführung besprochen werden. Fortgeschrittenenpraktika In den Fortgeschrittenenpraktika werden die experimentellen Fähigkeiten weiter ausgebaut und neue Arbeitstechniken vorgestellt. Die Versuche stammen teilweise direkt aus dem aktuellen Forschungsgebiet der Arbeitskreise. Ziel der Fortgeschrittenenpraktika ist es, die Studierenden an die Arbeitsweise und Arbeitstechniken im Forschungsbetrieb heranzuführen. Ausstattung Das Organische Prktikum verfügt über 6 Praktikumssäle mit jeweils 18 vollständig ausgestatteten Arbeitsplätzen für organisch-präparative Experimente. Spezielle Geräte können während des Praktikums in der Saalausleihe für die Dauer des Versuchs entliehen werden. Jeder Saal ist mit mehreren Vakuumpumpen, zwei Rotaionsverdampfern, Refraktometer, Schmelzpunktbestimmungsapparatur und einem Trockenplatz ausgestattet Das Praktikum verfügt über zwei moderne FTIR-Geräte (eines davon mit Diamant-ATR-Messeinsatz) und hat Zugang zu einem 400 MHz NMR-Gerät. Umweltschutz Für den Grobvakuumbereich werden ausschließlich Membranpumpen mit Emissionskondensator eingesetzt. Dadurch wird eine Kontamination des Abwassers vermieden und die Lösungsmittelemissionen drastisch reduziert. In den Grundpraktika wird weitgehend auf halogenierte Lösungsmittel verzichtet, die am häufigsten verwendeten Lösungsmittel werden separat gesammelt und nach destillativer Reinigung und Reinheitskontrolle wieder im Praktikum verwendet. Peter Kreitmeier - 02.12.2013 09:24 Fakultät für Chemie und Pharmazie Institut für Organische Chemie Organisches Praktikum Universität RegensburgUniversitätsstr. 31 93053 Regensburg

OCP II, Lehramt - Organische Chemie - UR OCP II, Lehramt - Organische Chemie - UR Fakultäten Home Veranstaltungen Forschung Studium Kurse B.Sc. Chemie Kurse M.Sc. Chemie Kurse LA Chemie Kurse B.Sc. Biochemie Kurse M.Sc. Biochemie Kurse B.Sc. Biologie Kurse M.Sc. Biologie Organisches Praktikum OCP I, CH und BC OCP II, CH OCP I, Lehramt OCP II, Lehramt OCP I, Biologie B.Sc. Alumni & Emeriti Links Intranet OC OCP II, Forschungsorientiertes Laborpraktikum Das organische "Forschungsorientierte Laborpraktikum" für Studierende der Lehrämter (Gym) , Vorlesungsverzeichnis 53421, wird im Sommersemester 2014 zusammen mit dem anorganischen "Forschungsorientierten Laborpraktikum" durchgeführt. Das begleitende Seminar ist Mi, 8-10 Uhr, H 45. Ablauf Im Seminar werden Studentenvorträge zu verschiedenen Themen gehalten. Der organische Teil ist in der 2. Semesterhälfte. Die Seminarvorträge der organischen Chemie sind zu Themenblöcken zusammengefasst (je 2 Studenten pro Block, jeder Student hält einen etwa 20 minütigen Vortrag). Das Praktikum selbst findet vom 2.6.2014 bis 13.6.2014 statt, jeweils nachmittags (bzw. nach Rücksprache mit Assistent). Platzübernahme: Mo., 2.6. 13 Uhr, direkt bei der Saalausleihe. Die Laboplätze werden werden zugewiesen. Weitere Informationen zum Praktikum (Versuchseinteilung, Zeitplan der Vorträge, Versuchsvorschriften etc.) finden Sie hier (nur innerhalb der Uni Regensburg). Themenblöcke zur Organischen Chemie Reaktionsmechanismen a) SN-Substitution und Eliminierung ? Überblick, Mechanismen Konkurrenzreaktionen b) Reaktionen von 2-Methyl-2-butanol und 3,3-Dimethyl-2-butanol mit Ergebnissen aus den Versuchen Farbstoffe a) Farbstoffe und Pigmente ? Grundlagen, Farbstoffklassen b) Synthese von Azofarbstoffen, Porphyrinen und Phthalocyaninen Cycloadditionen a) [4+2]-Cycloadditionen (Diels-Alder-Reaktion) ? Grundlagen und Mechanismus b) Reaktionen von Carbenen, [2+1]-Cycloaddition Moderne Reaktionstechniken a) Mikrowellenunterstützte Organische Synthese b) Mikroreaktionstechnik und Flow-Chemistry in der Organischen Synthese Materialien und Technologie I a) Modifizierung von Oberflächen mit organischen Molekülen ? Funktionalisierte Oberflächen b) Photolithographie, Prinzipien und Anwendungen Materialien und Technologie II a) Fluoreszenz: MorphFl, ein pH-Fluoreszenzindikator b) Thermochromie Nachwachsende Rohstoffe a) Nachwachsende Rohstoffe als Benzin/Diesel-Ersatz b) Kunststoffe aus nachwachsenden Rohstoffen Organokatalyse Peter Kreitmeier - 14.04.2014 18:43 Fakultät für Chemie und Pharmazie Institut für Organische Chemie Organisches Praktikum Universität RegensburgUniversitätsstr. 31 93053 Regensburg

Biology Lab Courses Labcourse I (CH,BC) Labcourse II (CH) Labcourse I (Teacher) Labcourse II (Teacher) Labcourse I (Biology) Alumni Links Intranet für Studierende der Chemie (B.Sc.) und der Biochemie (B.Sc.), SS14 Praktikum jeweils Mo.-Fr 13-18 Uhr., 7.4. bis 23.5.2014, Vorlesungsverzeichnis 53 050. Prof. O. Reiser, Dr. P. Kreitmeier Seminar (Vorlesungsverzeichnis 53 051): Vier parallele Gruppen, jeweils Mi., 11-13 Uhr, CH 12.0.18, CH 12.0.19, H 47 und H 45, Prof. Dr. Oliver Reiser, Prof. Dr. D. Diaz-Diaz, Prof. Dr. S. Amslinger und Dr. I. Shenderovich Vorbesprechung und Platzübernahme: Vorbespechung mit Sicherheitseinführung am Fr. 4. April 2014, 9-11 Uhr im H43 (Teilnahme ist Pflicht!). Platzübernahme Mo., 7.4. bzw. Di., 8.4.2014, jeweils 13 Uhr. Bitte beachten Sie, dass die Anmeldung zum Praktikum in FlexNow zwingend erforderlich ist! Ablauf des Praktikums: Das Praktikum beginnt mit einem Kurspraktikum (ca. 6-7 Nachmittage, bis Ostern). Hier werden die wichtigsten Geräte und Arbeitstechniken der präparativen Org. Chemie gelernt. Daran schließt sich das Hauptpraktikum mit ca. 8-9 Versuchen als "freies" Praktikum an. Hier werden die Präparate weitgehend selbstständig unter Anleitung des Assistenten bearbeitet. Begleitende Literatur: Kurspraktikum: "Arbeitsmethoden in der Organischen Chemie", S. Hünig, P. Kreitmeier, G. Märkl, J. Sauer, 2. Auflage, Lehmanns Media, 2008. Die Versuchsvorschriften zum Kurspraktikum werden bei der Sicherheitseinführung ausgeteilt. Hauptpraktikum: "Integriertes Organisches Praktikum I.O.C.-Praktikum)" mit den Versuchen auf CD-Rom, S. Hünig, P. Kreitmeier, G. Märkl, J. Sauer, R. Sustmann, Lehmanns Media, 2008. Beide Bücher sind im Paket für 32.95 EUR in der Buchhandlung Lehmanns erhältlich oder im Internet: www.ioc-praktikum.de. Weitere Informationen und Skripten: Alle Praktikumsversuche mit "Punkten" (pdf) Versuchsbezogene Betriebsanweisungen erstellen (nur innerhalb der UR) NMR-Etiketten (pdf, Zettel für NMR-Röhrchen zum Ausschneiden) Kurzanleitung zu SpinWorks 3.1.8 (Auswertung der NMR-Spektren, pdf) IR-Spektroskopie im Praktikum Kurzanleitung für das automatische Schmelzpunktmessgerät Peter Kreitmeier - 09.04.2014 09:53 Faculty of Chemistry and Pharmacy Institute of Organic Chemistry Universität RegensburgUniversitätsstr. 31 D-93053 Regensburg

Sem.), WS 2013/14 Das Praktikum findet parallel mit dem anorganischen Teil in 2 Gruppen statt. Die Praktikumszeiten für den organischen Teil sind: Gruppe 1: Di., 22.10.2013 bis 19.11.2013 Gruppe 2: Mo, 2.12.2013 - 18.01.2014 Die Platzübernahme ist jeweils am 1. Tag, Säle 1 - 3, Bauteil CH 33.0. Vorbesprechung mit Sicherheitsunterweisung Mittwoch, 16.10.2013, 12-14 Uhr im H 43, gemeinsam für den anorganischen und organischen Teil. Dort erfolgt auch die Gruppeneinteilung. Die Teilnahme an der Sicherheitsunterweisung ist Voraussetzung für die Teilnahme am Praktikum! Seminar zum Praktikum Das gemeinsame Seminar zum Praktikum findet am Mi. von 8-10 Uhr im H 45 statt. Ablauf des Praktikums (organischer Teil): Es sind jeweils 7 Stufen zu bearbeiten, die Zuordnung der Präparate wird zu Beginn des Praktikums (mit der Platzübernahme) bekanntgegeben. Weitere Informationen zum Praktikum (Versuchsvorschriften etc.) finden Sie hier (nur innerhalb der Uni Regensburg). Catalysis - Reiser Group - UR Catalysis - Reiser Group - UR UR Home Homepage AK Reiser Prof. O. Reiser Members Alumni Research Natural Products Amino Acids / Peptides Catalysis Coordination Chemistry Combinatorial Chemistry / Solid Phase Synthesis Reviews Publications Studies Contact Catalysis Visible Light Photoredox Catalysis: Generation and Addition of N-Aryltetrahydroisoquinoline Derived ?-Amine Radicals to Michael Acceptors P. Kohls, D. Yadav, G. Pandey, O. Reiser, Org. Lett. 2012, 14, 672-675 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/ol202857t The photoredox-catalyzed coupling of N-aryltetrahydroisoquinoline and Michael acceptors was achieved using Ru(bpy)3Cl2 or [Ir(ppy)2- (dtb-bpy)]PF6 in combination with irradiation at 455 nm generated by a blue LED, demonstrating the trapping of visible light generated ?-amino radicals. While intermolecular reactions lead to products formed by a conjugate addition, in intramolecular variants further dehydrogenation occurs, leading directly to 5,6-dihydroindolo[2,1-a]tetrahydroisoquinolines, which are relevant as potential immunosuppressive agents. A Recyclable TEMPO catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides C. Chinusammy, O. Reiser, ChemSusChem 2010, 3, 1040-1042 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/cssc.201000105 The aerobic oxidation of sulfides was accomplished with modified TEMPO A that can be readily recovered and reused by simple filtration. The importance of 1:1 and 1:2 metal-ligand species in chiral copper(II)-bis(oxazoline) complexes for catalytic activity M. Hager, S. Wittmann, A. Schätz, F. Pein, P. Kreitmer, O. Reiser, Tetrahedron:Asymmetry 2010, 21, 1194-1198 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tetasy.2010.03.030 The rate ratio of different copper(II)-bis(oxazoline) complexes for catalytic activity was assessed in a simple competitive experiment. The cumulated product enantioselectivity derived from a mixture of catalysts with antipodal chiral induction provided sufficient information to determine the relative rates in asymmetric Friedel-Crafts alkylations of indoles with benzylidene malonates, moreover, the discovery of non-linear effects in the reaction system investigated gave insights into the active and resting states of the catalysts. This approach can serve as a tool to screen the activities of different catalysts when detailed kinetic measurements are not suggestive. Iron (II)-Bis(isonitrile) Complexes: Novel Catalysts in Asymmetric Transfer Hydrogeantions of Aromatic and Heteroaromatic Ketones A. Naik, T. Maji, O. Reiser, Chem. Commun. 2010, 46, 4475-4477 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/C0CC00508H Chiral iron(II)-bis(isonitrile) complexes catalyse the transfer hydrogenation of aromatic ketones with enantioselectivities up to 91% ee, most likely via hydride transfer through imine intermediates, generated by in situ reduction of the isonitrile ligands, whereas iron acts as a Lewis acid to activate the ketone. A Recyclable Nanoparticle-Supported Palladium Catalyst for the Hydroxycarbonylation of Aryl Halides in Water. S. Wittmann, A. Schätz, R. N. Grass, W. J. Stark, O. Reiser, Angew. Chem. 2010, 122, 1911-1914; Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2010, 49, 1867-1870 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/anie.200906166 A catch-release system was established via the non-covalent attachment of a Pd(NHC)-complex on graphene-coated Co-nanoparticles. The immobilization through pyrene-tags was reversible at elevated temperatures, thus affording the homogeneous catalyst. The hydroxycarbonylation of aryl halides in water was performed with this highly active ?boomerang? catalyst in 16 iterative reactions. After each run, the complex was efficiently recycled, taking advantage of the extremely high magnetization of the nanosized support. Cu(II)-Azabis(oxazoline) Complexes Immobilized on Magnetic Co/C Nanoparticles: Kinetic Resolution of 1,2-Diphenylethane-1,2-diol under Batch and Continuous-Flow Conditions. A. Schätz, R. N. Grass, Q. Kainz, W. J. Stark, O. Reiser, Chem. Mater. 2010, 22, 305-310 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/cm9019099 Carbon coated cobalt nanoparticles were tagged with azabis(oxazoline)-copper(II)-complexes utilizing a copper(I) catalyzed azide/alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) reaction and the efficacy of the resulting nanomagnetic catalyst was tested in the kinetic resolution of racemic 1,2-diols via asymmetric monobenzoylation. The novel semi-heterogeneous catalyst was examined under batch conditions and in a continuous flow-type reactor. The extremely high ferromagnetism of the cobalt cores did not only facilitate the recycling of the nanobeads via magnetic decantation in the batch reactions, but enabled also a novel continuous flow-reactor design, which allowed the efficient agitation and containment of the particles without calling for sophisticated separation strategies such as nanofiltration. Cu(II)-Azabis(oxazoline)-Complexes Immobilized on Superparamagnetic Magnetite@Silica-Nanoparticles: A Highly Selective and Recyclable Catalyst for the Kinetic Resolution of 1,2-Diols A. Schätz, M. Hager, O. Reiser, Adv. Funct. Mater. 2009, 19, 2109-2115 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/adfm.200801861 Copper(II)-azabis(oxazolines) were grafted on magnetite@silica nanoparticles via click-chemistry resulting in a highly selective heterogeneous nanocomposite that can be efficiently recycled through magnetic decantation. The catalysts were used for up to 5 iterative runs in the asymmetric benzoylation of 1,2-diols with consistent high activity or enantioselectivity. Cyclohexane-1,2-diamines: efficient catalysts for the enantioselective conjugate addition of ketones to nitro olefins. R. Rasappan, O. Reiser, Eur. J. Org. Chem. 2009, 1305-1308 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/ejoc.200801263 Simple monosulfonated 1,2-cyclohexyldiamines are highly enantioselective organocatalysts for the conjugate addition of ketones to nitroolefins. Focusing on aromatic ketones as the most challenging substrates, selectivities of up to 98% ee can be achieved for the title reaction. Moreover, a three-component process between the primary amine catalyst, the nitroalkene and the ketone resulting in the irreversible formation of pyrrols has been recognized as a reaction pathway for catalyst deactivation. Immobilization of Cobalt(II) Schiff Base Complexes on Polystyrene Resin and a Study of Their Catalytic Activity for the Aerobic Oxidation of Alcohols S. Jain, O. Reiser, ChemSusChem 2008, 1, 534-541 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/cssc.200800025 The copper catalyzed [3+2] azide-alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) and the Staudinger ligation were found to be readily applicable and highly efficient for the immobilization of cobalt Schiff base complexes onto polystyrene resins. Stepwise synthesis of polymer bound Schiff bases followed by their subsequent complexation with metal ions, but also direct covalent attachment of preformed homogeneous cobalt Schiff base complexes to the resins, requiring modifications on the ligand periphery of the complex without affecting its coordinated metal center, have been successfully carried out. The catalytic potential of the so prepared Polystyrene-bound cobalt Schiff bases and its comparison with their homogeneous analogues was studied for the oxidation of alcohols to carbonyl compounds using molecular oxygen as oxidant. The immobilized complexes were found to be highly efficient and even more reactive than the corresponding homogenous analogues, thus affording better yields of oxidized products within shorter reaction times. The polystyrene-bound cobalt Schiff bases could easily be recovered from the reaction mixture by simple filtration and reused as such for subsequent experiments with consistent catalytic activity. Short ?/?-Peptides as Catalysts for Intra- and Intermolecular Aldol Reactions V. D'Elia, H. Zwicknagl, O. Reiser, J. Org. Chem. 2008, 73, 3262-3265 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/jo800168h Short Î±/Î²-peptides, containing conformationally restricted cis-Î²-aminocyclopropylcarboxylic acid units as turn inducing elements, have been found to be efficient catalysts for inter- and intramolecular aldol reactions. The tripeptide H-(L)-Proâ??â?²â??(L)-Pro-OH was identified to perform especially well in homogeneous and heterogeneous aqueous solution as well as in organic solvents. C1-Symmetric Versus C2-Symmetric Ligands in Enantioselective Copper- Bis(oxazoline)-Catalyzed Cyclopropanation Reactions J. M Fraile, J. I. Garcia, A. Gissibl, J. A. Mayoral, E. Pires, O. Reiser, M. Roldan, I. Villalba, Chem. Eur. J. 2007, 13, 8830-8839 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/chem.200700681 A thorough experimental and theoretical study of the enantioselective cyclopropanation of alkenes catalyzed by chiral bis(oxazoline)â?? and azabis(oxazoline)â??copper complexes, which comprise a new family of ligands that lack C2 symmetry, has been conducted. Surprisingly high enantioselectivities were observed with some of these ligands, which were rationalized on the basis of molecular modeling studies. The course of the asymmetric induction in connection with ligand symmetry and the implications for supported enantioselective catalysts are discussed. Synthesis of Polymer Bound Azabis(oxazoline) Ligands and their Application in Asymmetric Cyclopropanations H. Werner, C. I. Herrerí­as, M. Glos, A. Gissibl, J. M. Fraile, I. Pérez, J. A. Mayoral, O. Reiser, Adv. Synth. Catal. 2006, 348, 125-132 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/adsc.200505197 Aza(bisoxazoline) ligands were attached to various polymeric supports and the resulting immobilized ligands were evaluated in copper(I)-catalyzed asymmetric cyclopropanations. The efficiency of these transformations depends greatly on the polymeric support, on the protocol being applied for the immobilization of the ligands, and on the preparation of the catalysts. Cu(II)-Aza(bisoxazoline)-Catalyzed Asymmetric Benzoylations A. Gissibl, M. G. Finn, O. Reiser, Org. Lett. 2005, 7, 2325-2328 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/ol0505252 Racemic 1,2-diols and a-hydroxy carbonyl compounds can be asymmetrically benzoylated in a kinetic resolution in the presence of various Cu(II)-azabis(oxazoline) catalysts. A novel bisbenzyl substituted aza(bisoxazoline) ligand proved to be especially effective when immobilized on MeOPEG5000, giving 91 ? ?99% ee in 37 ? 49% yield for each of five sequential reactions. Cobalt(II)-Azabis(oxazoline)-Catalyzed Conjugate Reduction of ?,?-Unsaturated Carbonyl Compounds. C. Geiger, P. Kreitmeier, O. Reiser, Adv. Synth. Catal. 2005, 347, 249-254 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/adsc.200404295 Azabis(oxazolines) prove to be superior ligands for the enantioselective, cobalt(II)-catalyzed conjugate reduction of ?,?-unsaturated carbonyl compounds with sodium borohydride. ?-Trisubstituted ?,?-unsaturated esters and amides as well as ?-butenolides are readily converted to their corresponding saturated counterparts with enantioselectivities up to 97% ee. The importance of complex stability for asymmetric copper-catalyzed cyclopropanations in [emim][OTf] ionic liquid: the bis(oxazoline)-azabis(oxazoline) case J. M. Fraile, J. I. Garcí­a, C. I. Herrerías, J. A. Mayoral, O. Reiser, M. Vaultier, Tetrahedron Lett. 2004, 45, 6765-6768 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tetlet.2004.07.030 Azabis(oxazoline)?Cu complexes are more stable than their analogous based on bis(oxazoline) ligands, leading to improved recoverability (up to 8 times) when used in ionic liquid medium. The solution of the chiral catalyst can be reused even in different enantioselective cyclopropanation reactions with high enantiomeric excess (>90%). The role of binding constant in the efficiency of chiral catalysts immobilized by electrostatic interactions. The case of azabis(oxazoline)-copper complexes J. M. Fraile, J. I. Garcí­a, C. I. Herrerí­as, A. Mayoral, O. Reiser, A. Socuéllamos, H. Werner, Chem. Eur. J. 2004, 10, 2997-3005 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/chem.200305739 Azabis(oxazoline)-copper complexes are considerably more stable than the analogous bis(oxazoline)-copper complexes, as shown by theoretical calculations. The enhanced stability allows the efficient immobilization by means of electrostatic interactions with different anionic supports, such as clays and nafion-silica nanocomposites, without the loss of ligand observed with bis(oxazolines). In this way, enantioselectivities around 90% ee are obtained in the cyclopropanation reaction between styrene and ethyl diazoacetate with an easily recoverable solid catalyst. Improved Synthesis of Aza-bis(oxazoline) Ligands H. Werner, R. Vicha, A. Gissibl, O. Reiser, J. Org. Chem. 2003, 68, 10166-10168 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/jo0350920 A straightforward synthesis of chiral aza-bis(oxazoline) (Azabox) ligands from commercial available aminoalcohols is described. The new protocol allows access to previously reported Azabox ligands in considerably improved yields but also to new derivatives, including non C2-symmetrical ones. New Bis(oxazoline) Ligands with Secondary Binding Sites for the Asymmetric Cyclopropanation of Furans. M. Schinnerl, C. Böhm, M. Seitz, O. Reiser, Tetrahedron Asymmetry 2003, 14, 765-771 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0957-4166(03)00094-6 The diastereo- and enantioselective cyclopropanation of furans was achieved in up to 91% ee using a new set of chiral bis(oxazoline) ligands that are able to use secondary binding sites to enhance selectivity. In contrast, substrates such as styrene and N-Boc-pyrrole, with which no secondary interactions with the ligands can occur, gave only moderate selectivities (<50% ee). Activation of Nitroaldol Reactions by Diethylzinc and Amino Alcohols or Diamines as Promoters. G. Klein, S. Pandiaraju and O. Reiser, Tetrahedron Lett. 2002, 43, 7503-7506 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0040-4039(02)01768-9 Henry reactions of nitroalkanes can be initiated with diethylzinc in the presence of catalytic amounts of 1,2-aminoethanol or 1,2-diaminoethane. In contrast, in the presence of alkylated diamines as promoters, diethylzinc addition to the aldehydes is interfering with the nitroaldol reaction. Applications of Bis(oxazoline) Ligands in Catalysis: Asymmetric 1,2- and 1,4-Addition of ZnR2 to Carbonyl Compounds. M. Schinnerl, M. Seitz, A. Kaiser, O. Reiser, Org. Lett. 2001, 3, 4259-4262 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/ol016925g The enantioselective addition of ZnR2 to aldehydes (1,2) and cyclic enones (1,4) was accomplished using bis(oxazolines) as chiral ligands. The requirement for hydroxymethylene side chains in the ligands strongly suggests that bimetallic catalysts are decisive for high enantiocontrol in these additions. Aza-bis(oxazolines) - New Chiral Ligands for Asymmetric Catalysis M. Glos, O. Reiser, Org. Lett. 2000, 2, 2045-2048 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/ol005947k Aza-bis(oxazolines) are introduced as chiral ligands for asymmetric catalysis combining the advantages of easy availability of bis(oxazolines) and backbone variability of aza-semicorrins. Especially, the title ligands could be attached to a polymeric support, which allowed the development of easily recoverable copper(I)-catalysts for asymmetric cyclopropanation reactions. Kohls, D. Yadav, G. Pandey, O. Reiser, Org. Lett. 2012, 14, 672-675 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/ol202857t The photoredox-catalyzed coupling of N-aryltetrahydroisoquinoline and Michael acceptors was achieved using Ru(bpy)3Cl2 or [Ir(ppy)2- (dtb-bpy)]PF6 in combination with irradiation at 455 nm generated by a blue LED, demonstrating the trapping of visible light generated ?-amino radicals. While intermolecular reactions lead to products formed by a conjugate addition, in intramolecular variants further dehydrogenation occurs, leading directly to 5,6-dihydroindolo[2,1-a]tetrahydroisoquinolines, which are relevant as potential immunosuppressive agents. A Recyclable TEMPO catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides C. Chinusammy, O. Reiser, ChemSusChem 2010, 3, 1040-1042 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/cssc.201000105 The aerobic oxidation of sulfides was accomplished with modified TEMPO A that can be readily recovered and reused by simple filtration. The importance of 1:1 and 1:2 metal-ligand species in chiral copper(II)-bis(oxazoline) complexes for catalytic activity M. Hager, S. Wittmann, A. Schätz, F. Pein, P. Kreitmer, O. Reiser, Tetrahedron:Asymmetry 2010, 21, 1194-1198 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tetasy.2010.03.030 The rate ratio of different copper(II)-bis(oxazoline) complexes for catalytic activity was assessed in a simple competitive experiment. The cumulated product enantioselectivity derived from a mixture of catalysts with antipodal chiral induction provided sufficient information to determine the relative rates in asymmetric Friedel-Crafts alkylations of indoles with benzylidene malonates, moreover, the discovery of non-linear effects in the reaction system investigated gave insights into the active and resting states of the catalysts. This approach can serve as a tool to screen the activities of different catalysts when detailed kinetic measurements are not suggestive. Commun. 2010, 46, 4475-4477 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/C0CC00508H Chiral iron(II)-bis(isonitrile) complexes catalyse the transfer hydrogenation of aromatic ketones with enantioselectivities up to 91% ee, most likely via hydride transfer through imine intermediates, generated by in situ reduction of the isonitrile ligands, whereas iron acts as a Lewis acid to activate the ketone. A Recyclable Nanoparticle-Supported Palladium Catalyst for the Hydroxycarbonylation of Aryl Halides in Water. S. Wittmann, A. Schätz, R. N. Grass, W. J. Stark, O. Reiser, Angew. Ed. 2010, 49, 1867-1870 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/anie.200906166 A catch-release system was established via the non-covalent attachment of a Pd(NHC)-complex on graphene-coated Co-nanoparticles. The immobilization through pyrene-tags was reversible at elevated temperatures, thus affording the homogeneous catalyst. The hydroxycarbonylation of aryl halides in water was performed with this highly active ?boomerang? catalyst in 16 iterative reactions. After each run, the complex was efficiently recycled, taking advantage of the extremely high magnetization of the nanosized support. K. Maity, Q. M. Kainz, S. Faisal, A. Rolfe, T. B. Samarakoon, F. Z. Basha, O. Reiser, P. R. Hanson , Chem. Commun. 2011, 47, 12524-12526 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/C1CC14807A The utilization of a monomer-on-monomer (MoM) intramolecular Mitsunobu cyclization reaction employing norbornenyl-tagged (Nb-tagged) reagents is reported for the synthesis of benzofused thiadiazepine-dioxides. Facile purification was achieved via ring-opening metathesis (ROM) polymerization initiated by one of three metathesis catalyst methods: (i) free metathesis catalyst, (ii) surface-initiated catalyst-armed silica, or (iii) surface-initiated catalyst-armed Co/C magnetic nanoparticles. Efficient Synthesis of ?-Lactams by a Tandem Reductive Amination/Lactamization Sequence J. Nöth, K. J. Frankowski, B. Neuenswander, J. Aubé, O. Reiser, J. Comb. Chem. 2008, 10, 456-459 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/cc700202c A three-component method for synthesizing highly-substituted Î³-lactams from readily available maleimides, aldehydes and amines is described. A new reductive amination/intramolecular lactamization sequence provides a straightforward route to the lactam products in a single manipulation. The general utility of this method is demonstrated by the parallel synthesis of a Î³-lactam library. High-Pressure Induced Domino-Horner-Wadsworth-Emmons (HWE) -Michael Reactions S. Has-Becker, K. Bodmann, R. Kreuder, G. Santoni, T. Rein, O. Reiser, Synlett 2001, 1395-1398 A new protocol for the alkenylation of carbonyl compounds with phosphonates (Horner-Wadsworth-Emmons reaction) is described: Aldehydes react with phosphonates already at room temperature in the presence of triethylamine without further activation by Lewis-acids if high-pressure (8 kbar) is applied to the system. Based on this protocol a domino process was developed combining the HWE reaction with a Michael reaction, thus allowing the one-pot synthesis of ?-amino esters, ?-thio esters or ?-thio nitriles. Combinatorial Liquid-Phase Synthesis of [1,4]oxazepine-7-ones via the Baylis-Hillman Reaction. R. Räcker, K. Döring, O. Reiser, J. Org. Chem. 2000, 65, 6932-6939 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.102/jo0004916 A new method for the synthesis of [1,4]oxazepin-7-ones from readily available aldehydes and -amino alcohols was developed using the Baylis-Hillman reaction as the key step. To determine the scope and limitations of the method, a mixture library was synthesized from six aldehydes and six -amino alcohols on the soluble polymer support poly(ethylene glycol) 5000 monomethyl ether (MeOPEG) via split synthesis and analyzed by GC-EIMS. Those oxazepines that were formed predominantly were resynthesized in a parallel synthesis and fully characterized. Thus, we have shown that split synthesis on MeOPEG can be an efficient method to rapidly screen the substrate spectrum of a newly developed reaction sequence. Commun. 2011, 47, 12524-12526 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/C1CC14807A The utilization of a monomer-on-monomer (MoM) intramolecular Mitsunobu cyclization reaction employing norbornenyl-tagged (Nb-tagged) reagents is reported for the synthesis of benzofused thiadiazepine-dioxides. Facile purification was achieved via ring-opening metathesis (ROM) polymerization initiated by one of three metathesis catalyst methods: (i) free metathesis catalyst, (ii) surface-initiated catalyst-armed silica, or (iii) surface-initiated catalyst-armed Co/C magnetic nanoparticles. M. Seitz, A. Kaiser, S. Stempfhuber, M. Zabel, O. Reiser, Inorg. Chem. 2005, 44, 4630-4636 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/ic050014b New metal complexes with pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry have been synthesized with the chiral, pentadentate bisoxazoline ligand (R,R)-1, including the metal ions magnesium(II), iron(II) and cadmium(II). Helical Chirality in Pentacoordinate Zinc Complexes - Selective Access to Both Pseudoenantiomers with One Ligand Configuration M. Seitz, S. Stempfhuber, M. Zabel, M. Schütz, O. Reiser, Angew. Chem. 2005, 117, 246-249; Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2005, 44, 242-245 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/anie.200460843 ?2 or ?2, this is here the question! Depending on the heteroatom X the pentadentate bis(oxazoline) ligand will fold around a zinc(II) ion exclusively in the ?2- or ?2-configuration, both, in solution as well as in the solid state. Helical, non-racemic inorganic-organic hybrid polymers of cadmium halides with pentadentate bis(oxazoline) ligands M. Seitz, A. Kaiser, S. Stempfhuber, M. Zabel, O. Reiser, J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 11426-11427 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/ja0469784 A chiral, nonracemic pentadentate pyridine bis(oxazoline) ligand forms unprecedented P-helical inorganic organic hybrid polymers with cadmium halides. The one-dimensional chains consist of ?2-configured pentagonal-bipyramidal cadmium complexes with metal-centered chirality bridged by [CdX4]2- tetrahedra via shared halide atoms. In the solid state, the overalll helicity exhibits strongly directed orientation parallel to the crystallographic axis a. Predetermined helical chirality in octahedral complexes with a novel pentadentate C2-symmetric chiral bis(oxazoline) ligand M. Seitz, A. Kaiser, D.R. Powell, A.S. Borovik, O. Reiser, Adv. Synth. Catal. 2004, 346, 737-741 Web edition: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/adsc.200404020 The first example of new pentadentate bis(oxazolines) has been synthesized using a modular approach that readily provides access to this ligand class. This ligand allows the controlled transfer of carbon-centered to octahedral, metal-centered chirality, as demonstrated both, in the solid state as well as in solution. The characteristic CD-band has been identified for dicationic, octahedral transition-metal complexes with ?2-configuration.
